The stock is flirting with bear market territory — nearly 20 percent off its 52-week high — after having clawed its way back from those levels hit on the heels of the Cambridge Analytica privacy scandal earlier this year.

On a call with analysts, Facebook delivered some jarring warnings to investors, saying it expected its revenue growth rates to be lower than the year prior, especially in the second half of this year.
European DAUs fell to 279 million from 282 million the previous quarter, potentially related to the effect of the enactment of the General Data Protection Regulation in the European Union.
Facebook also missed on advertising revenue projections, with $13.04 billion compared with the StreetAccount and FactSet estimate of $13.16 billion.
At least three analysts downgraded the stock after the report, and many on Wall Street raised concerns about the company's policies and forecast.
North American DAUs remained flat despite the fallout from the Cambridge Analytica data leak scandal and fake news issues.
The company missed projections on key metrics after struggling with data leaks and fake news scandals.
As of Thursday's close, Facebook was flat on the year and up just 6 percent for the past 12 months.
However, average revenue per user in the region rose despite the lack of growth.
The set of regulations gives users more control over their online data.
It reached $25.91 per user, up from $23.59 in the first quarter.
(Facebook has a history of earnings calls that hurt the stock.)
